Karpathy Principle 1 — THINK BEFORE CODING: Don't assume. Don't hide confusion. Surface tradeoffs. State assumptions explicitly. Present multiple interpretations when ambiguity exists. Push back when a simpler approach exists. Stop when confused — name what's unclear and ask for clarification. Never pick an interpretation silently and run with it.

Karpathy Principle 2 — SIMPLICITY FIRST: Minimum code that solves the problem. Nothing speculative. No features beyond what was asked. No abstractions for single-use code. No "flexibility" or "configurability" that wasn't requested. No error handling for impossible scenarios. If 200 lines could be 50, rewrite it. Test: Would a senior engineer say this is overcomplicated? If yes, simplify.

Karpathy Principle 3 — SURGICAL CHANGES: Touch only what you must. Clean up only your own mess. Don't "improve" adjacent code, comments, or formatting. Don't refactor things that aren't broken. Match existing style even if you'd do it differently. If you notice unrelated dead code, mention it — don't delete it. Remove imports/variables/functions that YOUR changes made unused, but don't remove pre-existing dead code unless asked. Every changed line should trace directly to the user's request.

Karpathy Principle 4 — GOAL-DRIVEN EXECUTION: Define success criteria. Loop until verified. Transform imperative tasks into verifiable goals. "Add validation" becomes "Write tests for invalid inputs, then make them pass." For multi-step tasks, state a brief plan with verification checks. Strong success criteria let the LLM loop independently. LLMs are exceptionally good at looping until they meet specific goals — give success criteria, not instructions.

User wants ALL Karpathy engineering principles followed at all times: (1) Think Before Coding — surface assumptions, tradeoffs, confusion (2) Simplicity First — minimum code, no speculative features (3) Surgical Changes — only touch what's needed, trace every change to request (4) Goal-Driven Execution — define success criteria, verify before declaring done. Source: github.com/forrestchang/andrej-karpathy-skills

Watch mode implemented (commit 9a6a97f). FileWatcher class polls every 5s for .md file changes (triggers incremental semantic re-index) and .blog_memory.jsonl changes (triggers lazy reload). MCP server runs watcher as daemon thread automatically. CLI has --watch flag for foreground mode. No new dependencies.

MCP server hanging bug fixed (commit 981c42a). Two root causes: (1) numpy and sentence-transformers write to stdout during import, corrupting JSON-RPC stdio stream — fixed with module-level imports behind stdout→stderr redirect + env vars (TRANSFORMERS_VERBOSITY, TOKENIZERS_PARALLELISM, HF_HUB_DISABLE_PROGRESS_BARS, TQDM_DISABLE). (2) Blocking model load/encode starves asyncio event loop — fixed by converting 5 tools to async with anyio.to_thread.run_sync. All 13/13 tools verified passing.

When user asks for new blog ideas, use the prompt file "Prompt - deep post ideas.md" to generate new blog profiles/outlines, and save them in the "Post Outlines" directory.

When user asks to create new blog posts from previously generated outlines, use the prompt file "Prompt - thought partner and blog writer.md" to generate each full blog post, and save the output to the "Blog Posts" directory.

When generating new blog outlines, always check existing outlines in the "Post Outlines" directory first to avoid duplicating topics. Only generate ideas that are genuinely new and distinct from what already exists.
